meaning_mnemonic:
When you have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> as someone else, you are in <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary> with them. They have an opinion or feeling about something, and you're <vocabulary>feeling the same</vocabulary> way.

同感 is a word used to express agreement, often with a sense of shared feeling. You use it when you hear a thought or viewpoint that really resonates with you — you totally agree with this person's take and feel exactly the same way. Preach!

What does <kanji>self</kanji> and <kanji>awake</kanji> mean in combination? This refers to <vocabulary>self-awareness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>consciousness</vocabulary> of yourself, or a <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary>.

Wondering about the difference between 意識 and 自覚? 意識 refers to a general state of awareness or consciousness, while 自覚 specifically relates to self-awareness. It implies clearly recognizing one's own actions, abilities, or circumstances, and is often used in contexts relating to personal growth.

You know the word 皿 (plate) and the word 洗う (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of <vocabulary>dishwashing</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>doing dishes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>washing dishes</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji>. The verb versions of those are <vocabulary>to be distressed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be troubled</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be renewed</vocabulary>. Like most verbs ending in まる, this is an intransitive verb, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. Something renews or gets renewed, or something changes. See? No direct object.

Although it's not often translated as "renew," 改まる implies a kind of renewal in the changes it's used to describe — whether it's the revision of regulations or the old year changing over to a new one. It can also be used for personal improvements, or describe a shift to a more formal demeanor in social situations.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get mixed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be mixed</vocabulary>. 

混ざる is used to talk about something getting mixed, without focusing on who did the mixing. You can remember this because the <reading>Tzar</reading> (ざる) of Russia presided over lots of things getting mixed together — peoples, languages, religions. The Tzar's empire was a big melting pot where all kinds of things got mixed together.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surplus</kanji> so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to be in surplus</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to remain left over</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in excess</vocabulary>. Too much!

The <kanji>surplus</kanji> is <kanji>measure</kanji>d and it's all <vocabulary>unneeded</vocabulary>. Yeah, it's definitely <vocabulary>more than needed</vocabulary>. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?

余計 usually carries a negative connotation, meaning there's <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary> of something, or it's not needed and could be left out. It could be too many things, or unnecessary words or actions it would be better not to say or do.

In terms of an <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>... well, that's <vocabulary>personal</vocabulary>, and depends on the <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.

The counter 個, which means <kanji>individual</kanji> on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>individual</kanji>. A better way to translate that would be to call it <vocabulary>one small thing</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> just for you is your own <vocabulary>private room</vocabulary>. How nice!
<kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>individual</kanji>s is <vocabulary>three small things</vocabulary>. The kanji 個 can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>overthrow</kanji> or <kanji>collapse</kanji>, and this is a transitive verb (like most verbs ending in す) related to those actions. It means <vocabulary>to knock over</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to bring down</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to defeat</vocabulary>.

It can be used to talk about physically knocking something over, as well as bringing something or someone down, like a government, or defeating someone, like an enemy.
When you're looking straight into the <kanji>face</kanji> of a <kanji>collapse</kanji> it means <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>difficulty</vocabulary> coming soon.

If someone <kanji>overthrow</kanji>s your <kanji>property</kanji>, it'll end in <vocabulary>bankruptcy</vocabulary>. Without property you're sure to <vocabulary>go bankrupt</vocabulary>, unfortunately.

Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? So here, you have <kanji>borrow</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji>, or more simply <vocabulary>borrower</vocabulary>.

This word is often used to specifically refer to borrowers in contrast to lenders.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thick</kanji>? Also <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing.
The <kanji>pressure</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pressure</vocabulary>. This can also be <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary> as well.
Check the <kanji>pressure</kanji> of your <kanji>blood</kanji>. It's your <vocabulary>blood pressure</vocabulary>.

When someone applies <kanji>finger</kanji> <kanji>pressure</kanji>, they're probably practicing <vocabulary>shiatsu</vocabulary>.

Shiatsu is an alternative therapy from Japan, which involves applying pressure with the fingertips to specific spots on the body. This word can also refer to any kind of <vocabulary>finger pressure</vocabulary>, logically enough!
I <kanji>exist</kanji>, I <kanji>suppose</kanji>... this is the kind of <vocabulary>existence</vocabulary> I have. I'm not really sure either way, and I don't care. Existence is futile, I suppose.
The <kanji>truth</kanji> is that you <kanji>exist</kanji> in <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>real existence</vocabulary>. Well, that makes sense, I suppose.
When you <kanji>exist</kanji> <kanji>outside</kanji> (outside of what? Japan, of course), you are <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>abroad</vocabulary>.

Even in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of your <kanji>dream</kanji> you're thinking about your body pillows. You're <vocabulary>crazy about</vocabulary> them, wrapped in <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary>.

Alternatively, this describes doing something <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary>ally, like running away from somebody or something.
A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>dream</kanji> is also known as a <vocabulary>nightmare</vocabulary>. Ah! Noooooo!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Pull Something Over One's Head

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>cover</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to cover oneself with</vocabulary>.

被る is used when you wear things that cover your head or face, like hats, helmets, and masks, or when cover yourself with something, like pulling a blanket over yourself. Figuratively, it can also refer to overlapping events — think of it like one event "covering" another on a timeline.

Since the kanji's other meaning is <kanji>incur</kanji>, 被る can also mean taking on a burden or blame — incurring responsibility, in other words.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.

You have a <kanji>husband</kanji> and a <kanji>wife</kanji>. Combine them together and they're <vocabulary>husband and wife</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>married couple</vocabulary>. This can also be added to a name to mean <vocabulary>Mr. and Mrs.</vocabulary>.
You have your <kanji>wife</kanji> and you have your <kanji>child</kanji>. These are your <vocabulary>wife and kids</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>husband</kanji>, <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>wives</kanji>. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is <vocabulary>polygamy</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The vocab has the added meanings of <vocabulary>eww</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>gross</vocabulary>, and even <vocabulary>reluctant</vocabulary>.

You know that 嫌 means <kanji>dislike</kanji> and this vocab word means the same thing: <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary>!

Though this word is an adjective in Japanese, it usually makes sense to translate it as a verb in English, because of the difference in sentence structure. However, a more literal translation would be <vocabulary>dislikable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>detestable</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Machine</kanji>s <kanji>dislike</kanji> everything. Their <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>temper</vocabulary>, is very sour. What about your mood?
I <kanji>dislike</kanji> him and I have <kanji>doubt</kanji>s about him. I therefore have much <vocabulary>suspicion</vocabulary> against him as well.

You hopefully know that this has something to do with <vocabulary>housesitting</vocabulary> (留守番). So, a <vocabulary>telephone</vocabulary> (電話) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your <vocabulary>answering machine</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>voicemail</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Public</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about <vocabulary>pollution</vocabulary>?
<kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> is so bad they call it <vocabulary>water damage</vocabulary>. Doesn't get any clearer than this.
Psh, that guy's <kanji>damage</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji>. He's what I'd call "mostly <vocabulary>harmless</vocabulary>."

The お is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means <vocabulary>butt</vocabulary> (or any other word for it, like <vocabulary>buttocks</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bottom</vocabulary>).
A <kanji>bow</kanji> and an <kanji>arrow</kanji>. Put them together and you have a <vocabulary>bow and arrow</vocabulary>.

Remember how 忘れる is "to forget"? Well, a <kanji>thing</kanji> you've forgotten is a <vocabulary>forgotten item</vocabulary>.

忘れ物 is a casual way to refer to something left behind accidentally, like an umbrella you forgot about and left on the train.
A <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>contraption</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>machine</vocabulary>
The <kanji>fly</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an <vocabulary>airplane</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>dangerous</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge <vocabulary>crisis</vocabulary>!
This is the noun form of <kanji>disaster</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>disaster</kanji> that does <kanji>damage</kanji>. Usually these are <vocabulary>natural disaster</vocabulary>s, though they could also just be regular <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary>s as well.

A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fire disaster</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>conflagration</vocabulary>.

火災 is a more formal version of 火事. It usually refers to a serious and significant fire that causes extensive damage or loss of life.

A <kanji>disaster</kanji> that is <kanji>difficult</kanji> is particularly difficult, making it more of a <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary>. Obviously a disaster that wasn't difficult wouldn't really be that bad, so a difficult one gets the "misfortune" or <vocabulary>calamity</vocabulary> label.
An <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is just that, an <vocabulary>earthquake disaster</vocabulary>. These are no good.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>smoke</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>smoky</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crime</kanji> and the verb vocab version can mean <vocabulary>to commit a crime</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rape</vocabulary>, depending on the context.

A <kanji>crime</kanji>  <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>culprit</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>criminal</vocabulary>.

Just note that 犯人 is mostly used to talk about the culprit of a specific crime, not criminals in general.

<kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>crime</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji> with you is your <vocabulary>accomplice</vocabulary> in crime. It's best to "take care of" these before the coppers get to them.
You're <kanji>certain</kanji> there is this <kanji>percent</kanji> chance it will happen? You know that this is the <vocabulary>probability</vocabulary>?

You <kanji>compare</kanji> the <kanji>percentage</kanji>, figuring out the <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> of one thing to another. This can also be expressed as a <vocabulary>percentage</vocabulary>!

比率 usually shows up in cases where you compare two numbers with each other, like the number of male and female students in a classroom.
This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means <vocabulary>certainly</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>surely</vocabulary>.

It is <kanji>correct</kanji> and you're <kanji>certain</kanji> of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very <vocabulary>accurate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>precise</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Stand</kanji>ing and <kanji>enter</kanji>ing are both 禁止 (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying <vocabulary>do not enter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no entry</vocabulary>.

While this type of sign will usually say 立入禁止, you may also encounter variations such as 立ち入り禁止 or 立入り禁止.

Hey, this <kanji>hole</kanji> is a really nice <kanji>place</kanji>! But no one knows about it because they think it's just a hole. That makes it a <vocabulary>hidden gem</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>hidden spot</vocabulary>, and you better hope the tourists don't hear about it.

穴場 is for places that are good but relatively unknown. You can use it for any kind of location — restaurants, parks, beaches, fishing spots only the locals know, or even a hidden study spot on campus that you always have to yourself.
What's your <kanji>nose</kanji>'s <kanji>hole</kanji>? How about your <vocabulary>nostril</vocabulary>?

A <kanji>hole</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a <vocabulary>conger eel</vocabulary>, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is <vocabulary>anago</vocabulary>, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
Through various <kanji>test</kanji>s over the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>, you have gained much <vocabulary>experience</vocabulary>. Time and testing is all it takes.
If you have <kanji>guilt</kanji> then you have committed a <vocabulary>sin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crime</vocabulary>. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>guilt</kanji> is to be <vocabulary>guilty</vocabulary>. This can also simply mean <vocabulary>guilt</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>crime</kanji> and you have <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Sounds like you did the <vocabulary>crime</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stinking</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>stinking</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>stinky</vocabulary>).
<kanji>Incur</kanji>ing <kanji>damage</kanji> creates <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary> and  <vocabulary>harm</vocabulary>.

When your <kanji>surplus</kanji> is <kanji>abundant</kanji>, you have <vocabulary>leeway</vocabulary> for a lot of things. You have plenty of <vocabulary>room to spare</vocabulary>.

余裕 is used to describe a state of having ample leeway for something. It means you can handle things comfortably, without feeling stressed or overwhelmed, whether it's about money, time, or just mentally.

You have such <kanji>abundant</kanji> <kanji>luck</kanji>! If you have abundant luck, you're probably also <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>, because lots of <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary> equals lots of luck, right?

A <kanji>writing</kanji> of your <kanji>theory</kanji> is usually a <vocabulary>thesis</vocabulary>. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? And to make sure you have a thesis in that <vocabulary>paper</vocabulary>? I do.
You have <kanji>reason</kanji> behind your <kanji>theory</kanji>, making it a real <vocabulary>theory</vocabulary> (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?).
Using <kanji>theory</kanji> and <kanji>reason</kanji>, you are one who uses much <vocabulary>logic</vocabulary>. Imagine this type of person, I bet you know at least one.
A place where people <kanji>meet</kanji> and do <kanji>deliberation</kanji>. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>conference</vocabulary>.

There is much <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>theory</kanji> exchanging when you are trying to present an <vocabulary>argument</vocabulary>. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."

This is <kanji>not</kanji> what you <kanji>thought</kanji> would happen during your <kanji>deliberation</kanji>. You thought it would be very normal. Instead, it's the opposite. It's full of <vocabulary>wonder</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mystery</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>marvelous</vocabulary>
To <kanji>prevent</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> someone from doing something is <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.

You're doing a <kanji>prevent</kanji>ion. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying <vocabulary>to defend against</vocabulary> something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to protect against</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>to prevent</vocabulary>, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
To <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>beforehand</kanji> is still <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>.
You're <kanji>distressed</kanji> and it's <kanji>difficult</kanji>. This is quite the <vocabulary>hardship</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>difficulty</vocabulary> you're feeling.

A <kanji>difficult</kanji> <kanji>injustice</kanji> to take from someone is a <vocabulary>criticism</vocabulary>. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect!
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>difficult</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>earthquake</kanji> is just another way to say <vocabulary>earthquake</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s is how you measure an earthquake. The 震度 is the <vocabulary>earthquake intensity</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>earthquake magnitude</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>seismic intensity</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seismic scale</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>surplus</kanji> (that's an extra!) <kanji>earthquake</kanji> is a quake that  comes after the main (non-surplus) quake. That's an <vocabulary>aftershock</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>mankind</kanji> (人類) is known as <vocabulary>anthropology</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fly</kanji>, and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>. In addition to flying, the verb also means <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary>. Just think of jumping as being some sort of... smaller version of flying, and this'll make sense.
You remember how 洗う is "to wash"? Well, when you <kanji>wash</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji>s you're doing <vocabulary>hand washing</vocabulary>.
When your <kanji>chest</kanji> is <kanji>burn</kanji>ing, you have what's known as <vocabulary>heartburn</vocabulary>.

When it's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>divide</kanji> something, that makes it <vocabulary>indivisible</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inseparable</vocabulary>.

不可分 is a formal term describing something that is inherently linked and can't be separated without losing its meaning or function.
The <kanji>possible</kanji> (可能) range of <kanji>gender</kanji> extends beyond two options. It means there's a <vocabulary>possibility</vocabulary> to identify with many different gender identities.
You've seen (hopefully) 音読み and 訓読み. This is a combination of the two. This is <vocabulary>on'yomi and kun'yomi</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Chinese and Japanese readings</vocabulary>.

The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a <kanji>plural</kanji> amount of a <kanji>person</kanji> you have more than one person, you have <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>.

Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, あの人達 (those people over there). Other examples: 男の人達, その人達, 向こうの人達, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
<kanji>Quiet</kanji> <kanji>quiet</kanji>! Do it <vocabulary>quietly</vocabulary>, please.

You know how 文句 is a <vocabulary>complaint</vocabulary>, right? Well, add する to make it a verb and you have <vocabulary>to complain</vocabulary>. This is a really casual way to complain though, usually used in manga or on social media. Keep your eye out for it!

Remember how 焼く is "to bake," "to burn something," or "to grill"? 焼ける is just the intransitive version. That means no direct object needed! So this verb means <vocabulary>to get baked</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get burned</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get grilled</vocabulary>. 

焼ける is used when something is heated and transformed by the heat. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from a muffin getting baked, fish being grilled, or pottery being fired. You can even use it when your skin gets a tan or a house burns down. Well, that last one is kinda sad. I hope it never happens.

You can distinguish 焼ける from 焼く because when cooking, you always <reading>care</reading> (ける) to ensure the food gets baked or grilled really well. You want to make sure it's properly 焼ける'd (heated through) to be safe!

You have an <kanji>electronic</kanji> (電子) <kanji>container</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji>. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. So basically, an <vocabulary>electronic device</vocabulary>, or more generally, <vocabulary>electronic equipment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>electronics</vocabulary>.

電子機器 refers to complex electronic devices like computers, smartphones, medical devices, control systems, and more. So while it can be used to refer to a wide range of electronic devices, it's usually not used for things like simple household appliances like toasters or kettles.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>stab</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stab something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pierce something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to sting something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning that you're the one doing the stabbing... Should I be afraid of you?

If you <kanji>pass through</kanji> the <kanji>road</kanji>s, you are figuring out which roads to use, when to use them, and essentially coming up with the <vocabulary>route</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>course</vocabulary> to take to get to wherever you're going.

Another verb version of the kanji 閉! This is a special one that can be either transitive or intransitive, so 閉じる means <vocabulary>to close something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary>.

閉じる is for returning things that have expanded open back to their closed state. It's used for books, umbrellas, web browsers, and even eyes and mouths. There are some overlaps with 閉める (you can 閉じる or 閉める a gate, for example) but 閉める is mostly used for things like doors, windows, and curtains.
The <kanji>read</kanji>ing <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is reading. They are the <vocabulary>reader</vocabulary> (of a book, blog, article, etc).

Where you <kanji>exist</kanji> is the place you're <kanji>detain</kanji>ed. As long as you're in this place, this will be your <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>, even if you're <vocabulary>staying in a foreign country</vocabulary>.

在留 is an official term used for people residing in a foreign country. You'll find it in phrases like 在留カード (residence card) or 在留外国人 (foreign resident).
The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you're all by yourself and only your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>exist</kanji>s, you probably have <vocabulary>full control</vocabulary>. You can do whatever you want <vocabulary>freely</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>at will</vocabulary>.

自在 is commonly used with the particle に to form the adverb 自在に. This describes how someone can handle something effortlessly, as if they have full control over it.
The place you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> in Japan is called the <vocabulary>Diet</vocabulary>. It's their version of <vocabulary>congress</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>discussion</kanji>s is known as a <vocabulary>conference room</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>discussion</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> talks about all the really important things that need to be discussed for the sake of the country. They are a <vocabulary>member of the Diet</vocabulary>. The Diet is Japan's version of congress. <vocabulary>Diet members</vocabulary> discuss really important matters.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You have 最, which means <kanji>most</kanji>, and 後尾, which means something like "back" or "rear" (<kanji>behind</kanji> + <kanji>tail</kanji>). When you're at the most back part of something, you might find yourself at the <vocabulary>end of a line</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>end of a queue</vocabulary>.

最後尾 is often seen on signs at the end of a long line to help people locate where to join the queue.
This is a combination of the words 天気, meaning "weather," and 予報 meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the <vocabulary>weather forecast</vocabulary>!
You <kanji>dislike</kanji> someone so <kanji>bad</kanji>ly that it turns to <vocabulary>disgust</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary>.

The person in charge of <kanji>long</kanji> <kanji>discussion</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>chairman</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>speaker</vocabulary>. They also say who gets to talk and for how long.

Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have <vocabulary>senior high school</vocabulary>! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate). 

Fun fact: 高校 is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?

<kanji>Throat</kanji> <kanji>candy</kanji> is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a <vocabulary>cough drop</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>throat lozenge</vocabulary>. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means that it just happens, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>pass through</kanji> somewhere for a <kanji>reason</kanji>, so you're going <vocabulary>via</vocabulary> that place.

What <kanji>kind</kanji>s of <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s are you going to sow? Think about all the different kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.

This can also mean <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, as in a source of worry or joy, or even of a good story.

Here we have <kanji>nothing</kanji>, followed by the verb なる. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be <vocabulary>to be gone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.

This can be translated in various ways depending on the situation, but just remember that it always refers to something changing from being there, to not being there.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>connect</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to connect something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie something to</vocabulary> something else. Like connect people, hold hands, connect a cable to a charger, etc.

Figuratively, when you want to connect something over time, like a conversation, then you want <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary> something over time as well.

You might remember 実 means "truth," but it can also mean <kanji>fruit</kanji>! That's why this verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to bear fruit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come to fruition</vocabulary>. 

実る literally means <vocabulary>to ripen</vocabulary>, but it's mostly used figuratively to describe when hard work leads to results, like in the phrase 努力が実る (effort pays off).
